plan.name: Simple Calculator Web App
plan.description: A simple web-based calculator that performs basic arithmetic operations
features: User interface with display and buttons for digits (0-9) and operations (+, -, *, /)
Keyboard input support for numbers and operators
Responsive design for desktop and mobile browsers
Error handling for division by zero and invalid input

files.purpose: HTML skeleton containing the calculator layout and linking CSS/JS files
Styling for the calculator UI, making it responsive and visually appealing
JavaScript logic handling button clicks, keyboard input, calculations, and display updates
Project overview, setup instructions, and usage guide

tasks.title: Create HTML skeleton for calculator
tasks.description:
Implement the `index.html` file. Define the basic HTML5 document structure and include:
- A `<div id="calculator">` container.
- An `<input type="text" id="display" readonly>` element for showing the current expression/result.
- A `<div class="buttons">` containing button elements for digits 0‑9, operations (+, -, *, /), clear (C), and equals (=). Use `data-value` attributes on buttons to store their functional value.
- Link the external stylesheet `styles.css` and script `app.js` at the end of the body.
The HTML layout provides the DOM elements that `styles.css` will style and `app.js` will query for event handling. No dependencies on prior tasks; this is the foundation for subsequent CSS and JS integration.
tasks.integration_details: The file will be served as the entry point. CSS will target IDs/classes defined here (`#calculator`, `#display`, `.buttons button`). JavaScript will use `document.getElementById('display')` and `document.querySelectorAll('.buttons button')` to attach listeners.

tasks.title: Style calculator UI and ensure responsiveness
tasks.description:
Implement the `styles.css` file. Define styles for:
- The overall layout (`#calculator`) using Flexbox/Grid to center the calculator.
- The display input (`#display`) with appropriate font size, padding, and right‑aligned text.
- Buttons (`.buttons button`) with uniform size, hover/focus states, and a visual distinction for operators and the equals button (using classes like `.operator` and `.equals`).
- Media queries to adjust button size and layout for mobile screens (max‑width: 600px).
The stylesheet relies on the element IDs/classes introduced in `index.html` and will be loaded before `app.js` runs, ensuring the UI is ready for JavaScript interactions.
tasks.integration_details: Selectors match the HTML IDs/classes. No imports needed. JavaScript does not import CSS, but the visual layout defined here is required for user interaction.

tasks.title: Initialize JavaScript module and attach UI event listeners
tasks.description:
Implement the initial part of `app.js`. Define the following constants and variables:
- `const display = document.getElementById('display');`
- `const buttons = document.querySelectorAll('.buttons button');`
- `let currentInput = '';
- `let previousValue = null;`
- `let pendingOperator = null;`
Create the function `handleButtonClick(event)` that reads `event.target.dataset.value` and routes the value to appropriate handlers (`appendDigit`, `setOperator`, `calculateResult`, `clearAll`).
Add event listeners: `buttons.forEach(btn => btn.addEventListener('click', handleButtonClick));`
Export (if using modules) the key functions for later tasks.
This task sets up the DOM connections used by later calculation and keyboard‑handling tasks. It depends on the HTML structure from task 1 and will be used by subsequent logic functions.
tasks.integration_details: Imports: none (vanilla JS). Exposes functions `appendDigit`, `setOperator`, `calculateResult`, `clearAll` (to be defined later) via the global scope or as exported members if using ES modules. Data flow: button clicks update `currentInput` and eventually call `updateDisplay()` (to be defined).

tasks.title: Implement core calculation logic and display updates
tasks.integration_details: Uses variables defined in task 3 (`display`, `currentInput`, etc.). No external imports. Functions are attached to the global scope (or exported) so that `handleButtonClick` can call them.

tasks.title: Add keyboard input support and final event wiring
tasks.description:
Complete `app.js` by handling keyboard events and finalizing module exports:
- Register `document.addEventListener('keydown', handleKeyPress);`
- Implement `function handleKeyPress(e) { const key = e.key; if (/^[0-9]$/.test(key)) { appendDigit(key); } else if (['+','-','*','/'].includes(key)) { setOperator(key); } else if (key === 'Enter' || key === '=') { calculateResult(); } else if (key === 'Escape' || key === 'c' || key === 'C') { clearAll(); } }
- Ensure that pressing unsupported keys does not affect the calculator.
- Optionally expose an initialization function `initCalculator()` that encapsulates the listener setup, and call it at the end of the script.
This task depends on the variables and functions from tasks 3 and 4, and provides the final interactive behavior for both mouse and keyboard users.
tasks.integration_details: Continues from previous `app.js` definitions. No new imports. The `initCalculator` function can be called automatically (`initCalculator();`) ensuring the app is ready when the script loads.

tasks.title: Write project README with overview, setup, and usage instructions
tasks.description:
Create `README.md` containing:
- Project title and brief description.
- Technologies used (HTML5, CSS3, Vanilla JS).
- Feature list matching the specification.
- Setup instructions (clone repo, open `index.html` in a browser).
- Usage guide describing button clicks, keyboard shortcuts, and error messages.
- Screenshots placeholders (optional).
The README does not depend on code execution but provides essential documentation for users and future developers.
tasks.integration_details: No code integration; serves as documentation for the whole project.
